alert.note: Alert for Bristol (Massachusetts) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued July 16 at 6:06PM EDT until July 16 at 7:45PM EDT by NWS Boston
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 745 PM EDT THIS EVENING FOR EAST CENTRAL WINDHAM, SOUTHWESTERN BRISTOL, BRISTOL, KENT, NEWPORT, PROVIDENCE AND WASHINGTON COUNTIES... At 606 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1.5 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches are possible in the warned area, with the highest of those rainfall totals across Washington, Kent, Newport, Bristol and southern Providence Counties in Rhode Island. Flash flooding is already occurring, and additional heavy rains are likely to worsen or trigger new areas of flooding. Significant, considerable flash flooding remains possible especially in the Providence, Warwick and Cranston areas. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Law enforcement, emergency management, radar and automated gauges. Providence Emergency Management Agency reports street flooding in Providence. In addition, Rhode Island Dept of Transportation reports flooding on Interstate 95 near Elmwood Ave in Providence. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. Inundation in basements and businesses and road closures are possible. Rapid rises of creeks and streams to over bankfull. Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Providence, Fall River, Warwick, Cranston, Pawtucket, East Providence, Woonsocket, Coventry, Cumberland, North Providence, South Kingstown, West Warwick, Johnston, North Attleborough, North Kingstown, Newport, Bristol, Attleboro, Westerly and Smithfield. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR AND GAUGE INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Move to higher ground now. Act quickly to protect your life. Stay away or be swept away. River banks and culverts can become unstable and unsafe.
